summaries.body: New York City's St. Patrick’s Day Parade included two firsts: the participation of an openly gay Irish group, and the presence of Mayor Bill de Blasio.

display_asset.caption: Dennis Dunn stood in what he said was his usual spot on Fifth Avenue at the Saint Patrick’s Day Parade in Manhattan in 2015.

summaries.body: Corned beef and cabbage? Not so Irish, historians say. The dish is a staple of St. Patrick’s Day, but it may have originated in the United States.

display_asset.caption: The tomb of King Tutankhamen in the Valley of the Kings in Luxor, Egypt, in November.

summaries.body: Scans of Tutankhamen's tomb suggest that organic material or metal could be hidden behind the walls, encouraging those searching for the missing tomb of Queen Nefertiti.

display_asset.caption: Frank Sinatra Jr. performed at a private residence in Beverly Hills, Calif., in 2010.

summaries.body: Frank Sinatra Jr., who carried on his famous father’s legacy with his own music career, died Wednesday while on tour. He was 72.

display_asset.caption: There have been 25 cases of database misuse in the Denver Police Department in the past 10 years, including three in 2015, a report said.
display_asset.credit: Andy Cross/The Denver Post, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Denver police officers who were caught using criminal justice databases for personal use received light punishments, a report says.

display_asset.caption: Orca killer whales during a show at SeaWorld in San Diego.

summaries.body: SeaWorld said on Thursday that it would cease breeding killer whales, bowing to criticism over their treatment in captivity.

display_asset.caption: The Utah men’s basketball team stretched prior to practice at Pepsi Center in Denver on Wednesday.

summaries.body: There are many ways to watch the first round of the N.C.A.A. Tournament. Here are your options.

display_asset.caption: Colette Bourlier defended her thesis at the Université de Franche-Comté in Besançon, France, on Tuesday.

summaries.body: Colette Bourlier has become one of the oldest people in France to be awarded a doctorate, 30 years after she first began researching immigrant workers.

Adam LaRoche abruptly retired from baseball — and gave up his $13 million salary — after the president of the Chicago White Sox told him to limit how much time his 14-year-old son spent with the team.

display_asset.caption: Mayor Bill de Blasio, at Pier 15 in Manhattan on Wednesday, announced a $30 million-a-year ferry contract for Hornblower.
display_asset.credit: Uli Seit for The New York Times

summaries.body: Hornblower, a San Francisco-based company, was chosen to operate three new ferry routes in New York, angering New York Water Taxi, which says it will have to end its service.

Black students are four times as likely to be suspended from charter schools as white students, and disabled students are suspended at two to three times the rate of nondisabled students, federal education data show.

display_asset.caption: Some of the storks’ favorite menu items, the researchers found, were rotten fish, leftover chicken and hamburgers.

summaries.body: Thousands of storks have chosen to forgo their typical winter migration from Portugal to sub-Saharan Africa in favor of sticking around to gorge on garbage.
New research found that listening to music, even when alone, can be a social experience, because it stimulates the same neurons we get from being in the company of others.

Lin-Manuel Miranda, the creator of “Hamilton,” received assurances from the secretary of the Treasury about how Alexander Hamilton will fare in plans for a redesign of the $10 bill, which now features Mr. Hamilton's portrait.

display_asset.caption: Trees in temperate forests, like these redwoods in Northern California, may adapt to climate change by releasing less carbon dioxide than previously predicted by scientists.

summaries.body: A new study found that forests adapted to hotter temperatures by contributing less carbon dioxide to the atmosphere than scientists previously thought.

display_asset.caption: A caravansary designed by Nasser Mansouri for “Turquoise Mountain: Artists Transforming Afghanistan,” a show presented by the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery and Freer Gallery of Art in Washington.

summaries.body: An exhibit at the Smithsonian Institution has recreated an Afghan emporium in a nontraditional show largely controlled by Afghan artists.

display_asset.caption: A commuter walks by a closed Metro station in the District of Columbia on Wednesday.

summaries.body: As a Metro shutdown sent Washington commuters onto the streets, impatient travelers vented on social media.

display_asset.caption: Bald eagles, though once threatened, are no longer considered endangered.

summaries.body: Your break from politics: A live webcam fixed on a bald eagle nest — and the parents-to-be, Mr. President and The First Lady — may catch a hatching eaglet any time now.
The Belgian police have identified a 35-year-old Algerian man who was killed during a counterterrorism raid the day before as having potential links to radical Islam.

display_asset.caption: The Cook County state’s attorney, Anita Alvarez, was plagued along the campaign trail for her role in the case of Laquan McDonald, a teenager who was shot 16 times in October 2014.

summaries.body: Anita Alvarez, a prosecutor derided for taking more than a year to charge a white Chicago police officer in the death of a black teenager, was defeated in Tuesday's primary.

display_asset.caption: Chris Rock, the host of the Oscars, joked that three children of Asian descent were the accountants from PricewaterhouseCoopers. About two dozen Asian members of the academy said they felt the joke was a slur.

summaries.body: “The obliviousness was actually shocking,” the actor George Takei said of the motion picture academy's apology over jokes made about Asians at the Oscars ceremony.

display_asset.caption: A train departed a Washington Metro station on Tuesday. The subway system will shut down on Wednesday for safety inspections.

summaries.body: The subway system in Washington, D.C., will shut down all day today to allow for safety inspections prompted by a fire earlier this week.
At least 15 people in Wisconsin have died since November from bacteria that cause blood infections. Health officials are struggling to find the source of the outbreak.

display_asset.caption: Officials with the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement Homeland Security Investigations said in a statement that they had confiscated a “second century bodhisattva schist head.”
display_asset.credit: U.S. Immigration and and Customs Enforcement

summaries.body: For the second time in a matter of days, federal agents seized what they called an illicit antiquity that was scheduled to be sold during Asia Week in New York.
Amazon is seeking a patent for a system that would allow users to verify their identities with selfies instead of passwords.

display_asset.caption: About half of Elephant Rock, a natural stone formation in New Brunswick, Canada, crumbled on Monday. The tides that helped carve it out of the shoreline also played a role in its destruction.

summaries.body: The tides that helped carve Elephant Rock out of the shoreline in New Brunswick, Canada, also played a role in its destruction.
Dallas Seavey won his fourth Iditarod, finishing the Alaskan dog-sled race in record time, followed by his father.

display_asset.caption: Ninth-seeded Connecticut, above, which won the American Athletic Conference tournament last weekend, will face Colorado on Thursday in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

summaries.body: This year, there could be many N.C.A.A. tournament upsets that really won't be. In at least six men’s games in this year’s first round, the lower seed is the betting favorite.

display_asset.caption: Video image of a Fort Worth police officer pepper-spraying a group of motorcyclists Sunday.

summaries.body: A video appears to show a Texas police officer using pepper spray on passing motorcycle riders. The officer, who had pulled over a truck, is being investigated.

display_asset.credit: Robert Rausch for The New York Times

summaries.body: The U.S. just announced that you can travel to Cuba as an individual. Times editors and reporters answered questions on Facebook about the new rules.
